The aroma was not inviting as it was reminding me of the familiar "C" hops and I was bracing myself for another American wheat beer with too bitter of a finish. Nice, medium bodied, pale gold color with some haze and a snow white frothy head. December 23rd, 2013 - Boulevards 80 Acre Hoppy Wheat brings a lot of vivaciousness to a style that often sits and stews in its own, mulling, lazy flavors. The aroma begins with fruits and esters, replete with bananas, and even a touch of a grapefruit. On reflection, this makes a great deal of sense, given the title and style. Also, somewhere on the periphery of the scent, is a little white grape, giving a bit of a boost to acidity and brightness. The flavor is wheaty, but I note this in my notes as "wheaty?" The grain touch is lighter than I might have expected, replaced with a custardy banana mush, a touch of pear, and a nice-fruity hops balance. I actually prefer this over the usual cracked wheat flavor, though it might buck style guides.

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, best before 4/23/2015. Pours hazy deep golden yellow color with a 2 finger dense and rocky white head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Aromas of big grapefruit, tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, wheat, cracker, and herbal/grassy earthiness. Very nice aromas with bright citrus/piney hops and light-moderate pale malt notes; with good strength. Taste of grapefruit, tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, wheat, cracker, and herbal/grassy earthiness. Light pine/grassy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, lemon/orange zest, light pine, wheat, cracker, and herbal/grassy earthiness on the finish for a short bit. Very nice complexity of bright citrus/piney hops and light-moderate pale malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and light-medium bodied; with a very smooth, crisp, and lightly sticky/bready mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish as expected of 5.5%. Overall this is a very nice hoppy pale wheat ale. All around good compelxity and robustness of bright citrus/piney hops and light-moderate pale malt flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A very enjoyable offering.

Best by: 08/10/14 -- So it is past its best by date. Im pretty disappointed by that.

Appearance: Hazy light golden body with a fluffy white head that stands very well and leaves some spotted lacing.

Aroma: Very fresh hop aroma. Spicy with a bit of earthy bay leaf smell to it. Its very nice.

Taste: More of that spicy earthy flavor to it. It taste a bit like thyme. A hint of mint in the backgrond. I dont get any wheat flavor which is a bit disappointing, and there isnt any perceptible yeast character.

Mouthfeel: Its smooth and light, medium bitterness, and a bit drier than Id expect from a wheat beer...it also doesnt have the presence on the palate that most wheat beers have.

Overall: Despite being past the best by date on the bottle, the beer was good. I think it could be because the store I bought it from kept it refrigerated. The only thing that might identify this beer as a wheat beer to me is by the appearance...there really was no tell-tale sign in the aroma or flavor. The hop aroma and flavors are excellent. If you are an APA fan where you want a lot of hop flavor and aroma but not a ton of bitterness, this is right up your alley. If you dont like wheat beers, dont be turned off by this beer because it doesnt show. If you do like wheat beers, this leaves a lot to be desired. Overall it is a really good beer though, and the framework really relies on the hops...and if it were a house that frame would be made of solid oak.

12 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a hazy golden color. A large, foamy white head is formed with three fingers and a soft texture. It fades moderately quickly, and leaves spotty lacing down the glass.

S: There is a decent amount of grapefruit, orange, grass, and lemon notes that betrays a rock-solid hop profile. What Im not quite so sure about is the faint phenolic touch I also pick up. It sadly detracts from an otherwise very good aroma.

T: The flavor reveals lush citrusy notes throughout, and even an initial grapefruit-esque juiciness. It finishes with light touches of grass and lemon, and the dodgy phenols I picked up in the nose is kept in control here. Really likable if a touch mild.

M: I like how lush and creamy this is, helping to keep carbonation in check - and making it a bit syrupy at times. Aside from me wanting a drier finish, this has a very nice feel and great drinkability.

O: The more I have from Boulevard, the more I grow to like them. When done right, this is a style I really enjoy, and this beer in particular is a success. Id gladly make this a regular in my fridge.

Pours a hazy straw color with a thin white head, decent retention and lacing. Nose doesnt offer much (kinda pissy to be honest) but mouth is a different story. Crispy dry with some citrus (lemon, grapefruit) and piney notes, medium body and some bread towards the end. Reminds me a bit of Gumballhead, but definitely its own brew. Once again, yay BBC.

Pours a milky yellow-gold with a 2 finger, frothy white head. Aroma is full of citrus (smells very cascade-like) hops, a little pine, dusty wheat, fruity notes and a light bready note. Flavor is sweetish wheat and lemon up front, some mineral, bready yeast, sweet hay and leafy citrusy hops. Sweet grapefuit, dough and lemon to the finish. Much less hoppy in flavor than aroma, with very little bitterness. Palate is a little heavy for a 5.5% beer with such a crisp aroma and flavor, add the overly light (for this beer), a little bit of chalkiness and it really does a bit of a disservice to the other components, keeping the beer from being as light and refreshing as it should be. Pretty nice wheat ale all things considered, but the aroma really sets you up for an experience that the beer just doesnt match otherwise.
This was a little too thick on the palate for me.  It was good but it was nowhere near Boulevards normal wheat beer.  Not bad but nothing to write home about.

12oz bottle.  They were all sold out at Flying Saucer, I see why...its awesome!  Stable, 1/2-finger head.  Hoppy AND wheaty; Ill buy THIS hybrid!   Naysayers begone - this is way better than it sounds, amazing even.  Kind of like salted caramel - it sounds funny, but tastes delicious.  Its exactly what it advertises, and he excels at it.  Great full body, medium hoppyness and sweet wheatness!

Cloudy yellow pour, big foamy head.  Piney hops in the nose along with fresh biscuits.  Medium sweet.  Toast and grapefruits on the way out, with a slap of hop bitterness.  Ends a little awkward.  Most surely a hybrid style, different but drinkable.

Hazy, yellow pour with a white head.  The hoppy aroma has pine, grapefruit, and wheat.  The light body has a crisp texture with lively carbonation.  It has a bitter taste with some grapefruit rind flavor and a mildly dry finish.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a medium, well retained white head, with some lacing, over a cloudy yellow (SRM 3) body......nose is pine, grapefruit, cereal.....taste is pine, resin, grapefruit peel, light cereal, slight lemon, moderate bitter finish.....mouth feel light, carbonation adds tingle. This is a very different Wheat. The hops dominate both aroma and flavor making for an interesting and successful experiment. BJCP 7/3/14/4/7
Love the combo of hops and wheat!  I could drink it in the summer and through the winter.  Im glad they make it all year long.
Hazy yellow color with a medium head.  Aroma of citrus, honey and bread.  Flavor of wheat.  Very light lemon.
Pour is a cloudy yellow with a large white head.  Aroma is of pine hops and lemon juice.  Flavor is again hoppy and citrus fruity with a bitter finish.  Light but flavorful and refreshing.

(12oz bottle) cloudy light gold, soapy white bubbles. Nose of sweet candied hops, wheat, Marshmallow, orange pulp, rich. Taste of Wheat, light sweet citrus hops, candied orange, nothing over the top, refreshing, juicy stone fruit, I could drink this all the time in the summer.

Pours a hazy golden-orange with a huge rocky eggshell head that sticks around for a while. Nose involves grassy notes, some pine, orange, mango, and some dirty yeasty notes. Taste is pretty sweet with some bitterness. Lighter bodied with a decently bitter finish. Not bad as a hoppy thirst-quencher. Some of the aromatics seemed to clash with each other. A decent brew, and maybe something to satiate the Gumballhead crowd when they cant find their go-to brew.

Bottle. A medium gold hazy brew with a long lasting brilliant white head. A woody and strong grapefruit nose. There is also rich bread crust. This tastes like grapefruit and bread crust up front. This finishes smooth with some peanuts and salt. This is bright and clean with notes of wood in the aftertaste. Tingly with lots of carbonation.
Bottle. Pours a glowing yellow green color with a large foamy head. Notes of lemon bars, fresh cut grass, green and floral hops, and citrus. Great balance and mouthfeel. I like it.
Pours bright yellow, hazy to. Aroma sweet lemon citrus. It basically tastes like an American wheat with a little more piney hops. Extremely drinkable, very refreshing. Good summer beer.
Bottle.  Strong grass/hay hops aroma  Hazy bright yellow with large white head.  Light lemon malt and lightly bitter herbal/hay flavor.  Funky and different.

Crazy clean lemony intrusive aroma. Pillowy white head golden haz with some milky ness very simple but super enjoyable velvety citrus with offsetting sweet and slight bitterness. Not trying to be a homer but this beer when super fresh is at the absolute apex of session beers.
Im not much for wheat beers, but really enjoying these hopped up types. Pretty hazy gold pour with a large wiezen head. IPA aroma. Refreshing, lemoin and grapefruit flavors. Good summer beer.

Bottle. Piney, floral citrus hops aroma. Hazy golden yellow with a moderate white head. Lemon, pine, floral citrus hops and light grainy wheat malt flavor. Light crisp body, lively carbonation. Really nice, well-balanced American wheat.

Just as they advertised - IPA with a wheat.  You have the lemon characteristic and finish of a wheat with the hoppy grapefruit characteristics of an IPA at the forefront.  I just wish it blended more evenly.
While not considered a "summer" beer...this beer would make a great hot afternoon beverage.  Great hoppy aroma, very refreshing taste!  Great addition to the already good Boulevard lone of beers.
I wish this tasted as good as it smells. Boulevard needs to turn up the flavor and bring up the ABV.

Pour out of 12 oz bottle into weizen glass, slightly hazy orange-yellow pour with nice fluffy, lasting white head, streaming carbonation.  Aroma brought notes of fruity peach, pear, white grape, some crackery biscuit, bread notes, hints of grass, spicy hops, slightly floral as well, also adds a touch of citrus with a bitter orange peel.  Taste is pretty nice but a bit muddled, some nice grapefruit, orange, leading into some crackery and biscuity sweet malts, touch of sweet white fruit in there, some white grape, slight hint of grass, finishing spicy, slightly sweet, slightly bitter.  Very different from the aroma, but pretty tasty overall.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2013 Pours a light hazy wheat with healthy head and great lacing.  Aroma is wheat, citrus zest, and honey.  Taste is a balance of wheat and honey up front, a hoppy kick in the middle, and a clean, mild aftertaste.  Lively palate, crisp and refreshing overall.  Not bad!
This beer is a great mix of a hoppy IPA smell and taste up front, balanced with a nice toasted wheat finish  The finish is mild and over quickly, quick enough where some of the citrus comes back around.  Very drinkable and refreshing. 7+3+8+4+17=3.9

Pours a cloudy bright yellow-gold with a thick white head. Aroma is all citrusy, grassy hops, very nice. Flavor is light and fresh, citrus and flower and grass again, with a nice, light wheat undertone. Palate is also light and fresh, not overly carbonated but still light enough to be refreshing. This is a truly excellent new style of beer that combines the very best of IPA and American wheat beer. One of the best and most refreshing summer beers available.

For me a very citrus-y style beer.  I expected the beer to be rather bitter with all the references to hops however the bitterness was pretty minor.  I did get a sort of "lemon" flavor while my wife and sister in law said it was grapefruit.  I am not a fan of citrus so it was not one I would buy again but better than I anticipated.

12oz bottle from Binnys Plainfield. Pours a cloudy, yellow-gold colored body with an inch thick, frothy, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is lemon hops with some florals, light pines, and grass. Crisp, grainy wheats with some notes of tropical fruits and grapefruits. Flavor is similar. Light and clean, crisp wheats with a light grain and a touch of sweetness. Real nice lemon quality to the hops with some florals, tropical fruits, a light pine and grass, and a touch of grapefruit. Finishes crisp and clean with a light bitterness before leaving a fairly lengthy aftertaste. Light body with a medium carbonation. Overall, this is a great beer. Not a hop bomb like Gumballhead, but really pleasantly hopped with a nice lemon and light tropical fruitiness and a crisp, clean wheat. Big fan of this one.

Bottle poured a cloudy gold with a lasting white head. Aromas of grapefruit, wheat, lemon zest and light earthiness. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of wheat, lemon zest and light grapefruit with a crisp lightly bitter citrus finish.

Pours a cloudy straw with a loose, fluffy, white head that leaves patchy lace on the glass. The nose is of citric and herbal hops alongside candy sugar and wheat malt notes. The palate is light-bodied with fairly soft carbonation and a touch of a sour-twinge bitterness at the finish. Citric hops backed by a wheaty malt backing, the hop flavor lingers in the finish without the lingering bitterness you get from an IPA (or an APA for that matter). This is an interesting beer, I cant think of any other "hoppy wheat" beers, that Ive tried, where the hop presence is so pronounced in the nose and flavor profiles but so conspicuously absent on the palate. Without the tongue-squeezing bitterness of a Gumballhead or Schneider-Brooklyner collaboration, this may not fill-the-bill for someone craving hop bitterness, but it is definitely one of the most flavorful and sessionable wheat beers on the market, today. Nice job guys.

Pours a cloudy, carbonated yellow with an average white head.  Aroma is floral and wheaty, with grass and touches of lemon.  Initial hoppy taste that quickly flattens out.  Flavors include wheat, lemon, and grass.  Enough flavor in here to make it alright, but the palate is rather thin and watery.  This one does not really wow me.  For something that advertises itself as hoppy, I was expecting much more so.

Pours a very light straw color with an almost white look to it.  Little to no head on the pour and it disappeared to nothing.  Hoppy smell.  Hoppy and decent bitterness.  I dont think the light body of the wheat beer hold up to the hops.  The hops remind me of Zombie Dust (Citra).

Light head, some yellow in the lacing. Hoppy smell with citrus, and a little tropical fruit. Hop character in the taste but a mouthful of breadiness, slight tartness. Finishes with a nice slight bitterness. Would drink again.
Two finger head, white, creamy, cloudy, light brown color, earthy hoppy aroma, citrus lemon taste almost acidic.
(tasting at Des Peres Schnucks) light gold. Citrus/orange aroma. Flavor is light wheat malt with citrus and orange.

Nice looking wheat beer.  The head was two fingers and lasted forever, leaving sticky lace.  The beer is pretty much like their regular wheat beer in color and clarity, tan and fairly cloudy.  I suspect theres overlap in the recipes, but not just from the appearance.  

The aroma is quite hoppy, also bready, with a little fruit and wheat too.

Taste is a bit odd, but delicious.  It really tastes like boulevard wheat with a bunch of hops in it.  Its got yeasty notes, wheat, citrus, grassy hops, malt, lots of good stuff in there.

Body is typically wheat beer, light and easy to drink, but almost chewy with body.  A lightly sweet, hoppy aftertaste denotes the finish.

Its definitely a very different beer, and I like it.  Wonderful for summer laziness.  Ill definitely be drinking this one again.  Great value too.
Pours hazy yellow with big white head. Aroma is primarily citrus hops. Flavor is similarly hoppy with grapefruit most prominent. Think muted IPA flavor without the bitterness.
Hazy golden orange with a good sized off-white head. Aroma is floral with citrus, wheat and perfume. Taste is of citrus, wheat, light grass.

bottle.  hazed yellow body with a white head. nose of grapefruit, pine resin, dishsoap foam and citronella candle (both the waxy petroleum base and the burning wick)... its like the DEET insect repellent my dad would make me use as a child, the stuff that will melt plastic if you dont clean it off your hands.  medium-light body, waxy texture, dull and lifeless carbonation with muted wheat and malt flavor soaked in grapefruit and lemon pith-like citrus.  medium bitterness; medium-low acid; mostly dry.  lingering waxy finish with an abrupt flattening of the body late. resinous, oily / waxy texture, difficult to enjoy, and difficult to get past the citronella candle resemblance.
Hazy pale yellow with a white head.  Hoppy aroma with definite grapefruit notes.  Crisp and fruity.

Bottle. The look is clear, foamy white head, and golden in color. The smell hops, wheat, lemon, grass, and cleaning solution.  The taste is fruity hops, wheat, lemon, low but pleasant bitterness and nice.
This is a very tasty wheat ipa.  It has the taste youd expect from an ipa and the smoothness youd expect from a wheat beer.
Poured into a Boulevard Tulip.  Not much lacing.  Citrusy quality I look for in an IPA finishes with that Boulevard signature wheat taste.  Great session beer!

Botttle. Pours a cloudy yellow with a small frothy white head diminishing quickly. The aroma is a floral hops and wheat grass. Thin mouthfeel with a light citrus and a nice sweet finish. A decent wheat ale from Boulevard.
A great new addition.  Pours dark yellow and cloudy.  Citrus, grass, and resin.  Body of a wheat beer and slick mouthfeel.  Tried this one before it had a name at the brewery courtesy of Jason.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly lasting.
Body is hazy dark yellow, unfiltered.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain), moderately hoppy (resin, grapefruit), lightly yeasty (basement), with notes of gasoline and lemon zest.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter, slightly unclean.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Im surprised they managed to get higher alcohols out of such a basic low/med-alcohol brew, but the gasoline odor is distinctive and very off-putting.  Its not apparent right at first, but after only a few minutes in the glass it comes out and gets stronger with time.  And no, its not the room, my glass, hand/arm, or upper lip, I made sure of that.  That aside, this simply uses raw hop odor to try to make things interesting.  Sadly for me, I find the resinous type of hop aroma crude and non-enticing.  So even without the petrol stink, this wouldnt score too much higher...maybe a 5 for aroma. Looks nice though.

It poured a cloudy pale yellow color with a tiny white head. The aroma was of citrus and grass. The taste was of citrus, lemon, grass and wheat. A very good beer with hoppiness and citrus without the heavy bitterness.

Wow...! Impressive.. Pours hazy gold with an interesting lemon spice aroma taste is great. ? Just what it says.. A hoppy wheat beer... I would likeit with a tad less lemonbut i like the balance of hopps and wheat... Good summer beer...  nothing i would wanna sit down and have a bunch of..

Bottle. Aroma is of lemon zest and hops with the obvious wheat.  The taste is a nice blend of hops and wheat...definitely the hoppiness is the stronger of the two, and it all balances out well.  Im never surprised to find that a cheap bottle of Boulevard is exceptional, and yet again thats the case. 5.5% abv.

Im surprised how much I like this beer.  fruit, hops and a little bread on the nose.  Taste is sweet, grapefruit, orange, piney.  finish is bitter and dry; i want more of this.  Might be my new session beer

Pours a nice and hazy gold with a fair amount of creamy head that laces nicely. Smells of citrus rind, orange, lemon and yeast. Tastes as it smells with spice and a little hops and finishes with a dryness. Feels light in the mouth and quenches ones thirst very well. A session beer no doubt and on a summer day this is an oasis

Pours a hazy yellow color with a good sized head and good lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is big and pineappley, generally sort of citrus fruit forward, but clean with a little bit of the scent of fresh baked bread. 

The flavor is hoppy and fruit forward, lots of pineapple and orange with a tiny bit of banana. Lots of pleasant bitterness and mild bubblegum are both nice characteristics even if they seem an odd combo. 

Altogether bright and delicious.

Hazy medium yellow,light head.
Smells hoppy with fruit/citrus,ripe or tropical like.Melon mago,papaya.Juice.
Taste has same hop character but a mouthfull of wheat breadyness,very slight tartness.Some juciness.Some peppery like mild bitter in the finish.It taste like it should bitter like an ipa but its a wheat and some tartness does show in the finish making up for that.
The best drinking beer I?ve had. Great taste, better then there normal wheat beer. My new favorite beer from boulevard.

Hazy gold with a thick, soapy head that diminishes to a rather thick lace - aroma is a lively, zesty mix of tangy citrus, sweet melon and herbal/peppery hops - soft carbonation - flavor is initially sweet, with light tropical fruit flavors - the middle has some moderate citrus tang - tail end has some peppery hops, moderate herbs, some lemon rind - refreshing and lively - a nice addition to their six pack line up - if only the Stingo I drop 13 bucks on earlier this week were as good.

hazy gold pour with a thick foamy head.
aroma is citrusy, grassy, wheat, light clove spice. 
Flavour is sour-ish wheat, light spice, grassy hop. Melon and lemongrass.

I love this beer! Nice grapefruit and lemon aromas. Crisp hop bitterness lights up the tongue. Big citrusy flavors complement the tart and refreshing characteristics of the wheat. A great session beer that is not heavy but big on flavor.
very impressed!! finally someone has combined two great style of beers! citrusy nose, very palatable, dry towards the finish.

very impressed with this beer. This is Boulevard at its finest, a great beer without overthinking it.
Very citrusy on the nose with an excellent hoppy/wheaty finish, as sessionable as they come. To style, I think this is exactly what they were going for. I will be enjoying quite a few of these in this sitting

hazy gold. Lemon, melon, grass, yeast. Flavor is quite nice, just a hint of funky weirdness which isnt distracting. Finishes clean, little bitterness for the amount of hop flavor in this one. Snappy carbonation.

Foamy head, hazy gold color with lots of lacing.
Orange, grass, pine, cedar and cheese with moderate carbonation and creamy mouthfeel. Quite good actually-not too sweet or bitter. Great hot weather beer.
A hazy light yellow beer with a small white head.  The aroma is tropical fruit, wheat, and grass.  The flavor is sweet and citrusy with a lightly bitter hoppy finish.
bottled, almost clear icy yellow pour with thin  foam ring, clean fruity wheat aroma, great melon, wheat and hard cheese flavors, nice finish

Very lite golden color. Was not a lot of hoppy taste, but came across really smooth. Would say it is like a heavy pilsner style beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The beer pours a slightly hazy straw color with a white head. The aroma has a good bit of pine, as well as some light orange citrus notes. There is also some nice wheat in the aroma. The flavor is very similar. The wheat really comes through up front, with some lighter pine and orange notes, as well as some grass and a bit of pepper. Thin mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Very nice.
Pours pale golden with a white head. Aroma is fruity, citrusy hops. Flavor is fruity hop and some wheaty malt.  Lightly bitter clean finish.

gold pour with a white head.  nose is fresh hops, lightly bitter, heavy tropical fruits, light wheat, spice, and lemon.  very light on the palate, wheat, lemon, citrus, tropical fruit finish.  very refreshing.

Bottle. Pours cloudy straw yellow with white soapy head. Aroma of pleasant bright citrus. Flavor is nice, light citrus and wheat. Light body with fizzy carbonation. Overall, very tasty, great summer brew!
Draft at the source, as Trst Beer #3.  Cloudy pale yellow color, small white head, solid lacing. Aroma of light lemen. Taste is lemon and tropical fruit. Refreshing.

Tasted at the Boulevard Tasting Room after a tour on December 17.  Im not a huge fan of the Boulevard Wheat, but this is a brew I can get behind.  The extra hoppiness in this gives it a bigger flavor, while not going overboard on the bitterness.  I cant wait until Boulevard actually releases this beer.

Multiple samples at the Boulevard tasting room, post tour.  Tour guide was good enough to supply me with a full pour!  Pour is a cloudy hazed yellowish white with a smallish white head.  Aroma is bright tropical pineapple fruit hop, orange fruit sweetness, along with the malt wheat, finishing with further sweetness. Taste is the bright tropical fruit hops, orange citrus fruit, both of which are balanced nicely with the wheat and malt.  The finish reintroduces the sweetness of the nose.  Fresh and vibrant, really nicely balanced. Palate is light to medium bodied, nice scrubbing active carbonation and a dry finish.   High level of drink-ability.  Nice, fun, alive interpretation of a classic.

Draft. Poured a hazy light orange color. The head was sticky and white with great retention and lacing. Light flowery hop, baking spices, and wheat in the nose. Light bodied and slightly sweet. Flower blossom up front with notes of vanilla cake and subdued butter in the middle. A bit of caramel emerged after the finish. Nice.

tap at brewery-this was the only beer they had on tap that i had never had.  pours hazy dark yellow light orange with a soapy fluffy white head.  nose is very floral like a flower garden lite bright citrus lovely flavors are lite wheat grains with a splash of hops not much in terms of bitterness but must have had a ton of dry hopping.  really crisp and clean with some tartness on the finish.  a very tasty experiment that more breweries need to make a standard (as in replace their wheat beer).

Very cloudy lemon yellow with a green tint. Medium aroma: lemon, wheat, a little muskly. Medium palate, a little flat but not bad, wheat & lemon. Not great, but as far as options go in Muscatine, IA, not bad at all
Sample at the KC Beerfest 10-22.  Comes a hazy pale yellow with a small white head.  Aroma of citrus, florals, malt and wheat.  Taste is citrus, hops and wheat.  Very nice!

Tap at Iowa City Brewfest.  Gorgeous fresh hop aroma, lightly grassy and full of fresh citrus hops, light wheat malt character, just fantastic.  Pours cloudy straw/golden color with a thick white head, good retention and plenty of lacing.  Flavor just as impressive as the nose; great fresh hops, cut hay, citrus, wheat, very crisp throughout, faint tartness in the background.  Sticky, fresh floral hops are really well done in this brew.  Light body, medium/high carbonation.  Incredibly flavorful and drinkable for a 5% abv beer, this will certainly be one of my go-to beers if/when it comes out in bottles, delicious!

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2013 --Tasting room hoppy wheat test brew on tap at blvd tap room. A solid hopped wheat with a bit more lemon citrus flavor  I would prefer this to wheat most any day. Bottle pours clear hazy pale yellow with off white head. Fruity tropical earthy herbal smell. Semi sweet bright lemon hop flavor along with minor tropical pineapple, mango, green apples, very light wheat grain spice but had the unfiltered filling grain attribute. Lovely carbonation, filling for a lighter beer. The tap is very close and very solid.

Tiny sample at 2011 Parkville Brewfest on 4/30.  You crazy kids keep adding festival brews!

Not too dissimilar from its unfiltered parent brew, cloudy gold/straw color with a thin white head (kinda hard to form in a 3-4oz sampler) with a faint nose of green wheat.  Flavor and finish are kicked up from the original unfiltered with a sharp hint of lemongrass (or just lemons) as the citrusy hops.  Finish is more bitter than the original, as expected, but not what you would call a seriously hopped pale ale...just a nice twist on the usual wheaty summer classic for Kansas Citians.

On draft at the KCBM 2011 Homebrew Competition.  Aroma holds no real surprises, with plenty of citric, fruity hop, lemon, faintly grainy, wheat malt and very slight esters in the background.  Thoroughly cloudy golden color, with a fine, lasting head, really doesnt appear to be any different than the standard Wheat.  Flavor is decently hopped as well, again with an overt citrus character from beginning to end, paired with a distinctly wheaty malt base, this showing through primarily at the finish, which is dry and fairly refreshing.  Some lingering leafy hop character here as well.  Bitterness is fairly light, surprisingly.  Body is light-medium, palate is creamy and effervescent.  Nicely balanced and refreshing.   Heck of a lot better and more interesting than Boulevard Wheat, but I am likely just burned out on that stuff.

Sample at KC Hopfest 2011.  Pours a cloudy pale yellow.  Has an almost white appearance.  Aroma of citrus and grass.  Flavor is citrus, lemon, grass, wheat.  Very easy drinking.  Has the hoppy, citrus, aromas without the heavy bitterness.  Quite good.

Sampled at St. Louis Microfest 2011 - big thanks to Boulevard for bring this rarity to our fest.  Pours hazy yellow with a small white head.  The aroma has lemony hoppiness, orange, must and wheat.  Medium body (fairly full for the style) with semi-sharp carbonation.  The flavor starts with spicy and lemony hoppiness, fullness from either yeast or wheat, clear american wheat and some orange.  The finish is very spicy and clean.  Nicely done.  Wish I could get this on a more regular basis.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2013 Keg at KCBM 2011 competition.  Hoppy for sure, this is all hops with a week backbone.  It came off too astringent for my taste.  The hops turned into a cleaning product instead.  I like the idea, but I would like to get something from the base wheat beer. 7/3/6/3/14.Oh, this needs a re-rate.  The bottled product is much better.  Damn great hop mix with a subtle background of light wheat beer.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Draft sample in the VIP tent at St. Louis Microfest 2011. Pours a cloudy yellow-gold color with a fairly small bone white head that settles into a ring. Aroma of lemon citrus, floral hops, wheat, sweet and pale malts, light tropical fruits, and even a little grapefruit peel. Flavor of floral hops, lemon and grapefruit citrus, pineapple, sweet malts, banana, wheat, and a little bit of a clove-coriander spice. The hops emerge a bit more in the flavor than in the nose. Light-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a juicy mouthfeel. Not amped-up to quite the level of hoppiness in some other hoppy wheat ales (Gumballhead, Burn Ward Wheat, Wheat Freak), but definitely smoother than those. Really nice variation of a style theyre known for.
